book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Do not keep telling her to push harder; you would only make her feel inadequate. Instead, encourage her: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the way! Come on, Baby.‚Äù

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: ‚Ä¢ If the nurse or caregiver wants the mother to push without a contraction or an urge to push, ask whether she can wait until she feels the urge.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Compliment her‚Äîtell her how well she is doing‚Äîafter every contraction.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: The baby may immediately cry and appear vigorous, or she may appear bluish and lifeless at first. But within seconds she begins breathing, usually with a gurgle and then a lusty cry. Immediately, the baby begins to turn more pink, and very soon she will be a healthy pink or ruddy color.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: It can seem as if nothing is happening, but you have to remain optimistic and supportive, knowing that changes are happening on the inside.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Don‚Äôt leave at this time if you want to see the baby‚Äôs birth. Things can change quickly.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: The most common positions are semisitting, lying flat on one‚Äôs back, side lying, hands-and-knees, and squatting. Supported squatting, lap squatting, ‚Äúthe dangle,‚Äù and sitting on the toilet are also useful at times.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: It can take an hour or two of pushing before the baby‚Äôs head is visible at the vaginal opening.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: You may be baffled that her labor has apparently stopped. Do not worry. The pause is temporary and will give the mother a second wind.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Using whatever suggestions work, remind her to relax her perineum: ‚ÄúLet go,‚Äù ‚ÄúRelax your bottom,‚Äù ‚ÄúOpen up,‚Äù ‚ÄúLet the baby out.‚Äù You might remind her to relax as she did during perineal massage

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: you watch this incredible process, you will likely find yourself totally engrossed. You almost hate to see the baby slip back each time because you‚Äôre so anxious to see him born. You must remember that progress is being made, and this gradual stretching is easier on both baby and mother than constant pressure on the baby‚Äôs head and continuous stretching of the vagina.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: ‚Ä¢ Be patient during the resting phase. Don‚Äôt try to rush the mother through it or make her push too soon.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: The descent phase usually takes up most of the total time of the birthing stage‚Äîfrom a few minutes to as much as 4 hours. The average is about 11/2 hours.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated

text: the woman‚Äôs behavior is being guided by her pushing urges, which come three or four times over the peak of each contraction. The urges last about five or six seconds, with three to five seconds in between.

text: Mop her brow and neck with a cold washcloth. Pushing is hard, sweaty work!

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: If the midwife or doctor tells the mother to stop pushing so that she will not injure herself or the baby with too rapid a delivery, the mother may find it difficult to comply. Help her avoid pushing by getting her to follow your directions: ‚ÄúLift your chin, look at me, blow . . . , blow . . . , that‚Äôs the way . . . , blow . . . ,‚Äù and so forth.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: You may feel more love and awe for the mother than you ever thought possible.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: If there are continual interruptions‚Äîa nurse or caregiver examining her, checking her pulse, taking her temperature or blood pressure, drawing blood, monitoring her‚Äîthe mother may become too unsettled to be able to keep a rhythm or regain her ritual. In this case you might tell the nurse, ‚ÄúIf we could get through a few contractions without interruption, I think she could get back on top of them. Is this possible?‚Äù

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Instead of trying to help her maintain a ritual during the birthing stage, help her maintain a good position for birth and encourage her to relax her perineum as she pushes

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Contractions of the uterus‚Äîthe strongest muscle in the human body‚Äîwhich reach maximum intensity during this stage. (Try doing several chin-ups for a minute at a time. The muscle pain in your arms is similar to the kind of pain caused by uterine contractions, but less.)

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Other birth partners have helped mothers know when a contraction has passed the halfway point by counting breaths. Once you know about how many breaths it takes the mother to get through a contraction, you can tell her when she is ‚Äúon the downside.‚Äù

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: When she finds she has to stop everything for 30 seconds or so at each contraction‚Äôs peak, she stops trying to distract herself and begins using a ritual.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Stretching of the cervix as it opens. (Try sitting on the floor with your legs out straight, and bending forward as far as possible with your hands grasping your lower legs. This will give you a sense of the nature of the pain caused by the cervix stretching.)

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: If a woman understands why contractions hurt; if she is continuously nurtured and encouraged by humane, caring, confident people in a peaceful and safe environment; if she is free to move about to find greater comfort; and if she knows effective ways to respond to her contractions, fear gives way to mastery, confidence, and a sense of well-being. She copes; she does not suffer.

book: The Birth Partner, 4th Edition, Completely Revised and Updated
author: Penny Simkin
text: Do not interrupt her ritual during a contraction by asking a question or telling her to try something else.

It really helps reduce her discomfort if she releases tension, remains still, and goes limp throughout her body.
